[[Bentley|Bentley Motors Ltd.]] | Best Finish = 1st ({{24hLM|1924}}) | Class Wins = 1 ({{24hLM|1924}}) }} '''John Francis Duff''' (January 17, 1895 â January 8, 1958) was a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Auto racing|racecar driver]] who won many races and has been inducted in the [[Canadian Motorsport Hall of Fame]].[http://www.cmhf.ca/member_JOHN_DUFF.html CMHF Citation] He was one of only two Canadians who raced and won on Englandâs famous [[Brooklands]] Motor Course. The other, [[Kay Petre]], is already an honoured member of the CMHF. Duff was the first Canadian to race in the legendary [[24 Hours of Le Mans]]. To date, he is the only Canadian to win the overall classification at Le Mans. Duff also held over fifty world records for speed and endurance. Those records were sanctioned by the [[AIACR]], the forerunner of todayâs [[FIA]]. They included both class and absolute records. His achievements helped make the name of the [[Bentley]] car company. Duff scored a top-ten finish in his first [[Indianapolis 500]] and a top-three in his first board track race. Those achievements make him one of the preeminent Canadian automobile racers of the first half of the twentieth century. == Background == John Duff was born in [[Kiukiang]], [[China]]. His parents were Canadians from [[Hamilton, Ontario]] ''The Globe and Mail'', January 7, 1927, Page 3. who established a commercial outpost in nearby Kuling. As a boy, the rambunctious young Duff was sent to Hamilton for a good Victorian education. He lived there until he was sixteen.See 1911 Census of Canada. In 1912, Duff was back in Kuling. When [[World War I|war was declared]] in 1914, he travelled across [[Russia]] to [[England]], where he joined the army. Gravely wounded at the [[Third Battle of Ypres]], Duff was sent to a hospital in England where he met and married his nurse. In 1919, John Duff learned how to drive a car and became a dealer. In 1920, he started racing. == Racing career == In 1920, Duff began his racing career at [[Brooklands]], a 2.6 mile long concrete track with concave banking known as âthe English Indianapolisâ. He drove a [[Fiat]] S.61, a 10 litre chain-driven car built in 1908. By August 1920, he was lapping in the same range as [[Henry Segrave]], one of the great Brooklands and Grand Prix drivers of the 1920s. Driving the S.61, Duff won the 75 Long Handicap at Brooklands in May 1921 at a speed of 104.19 mph. He won the 100 Long Handicap at Brooklandsâ mid-summer meeting, averaging 104.85 mph.Because of the wide variety of racing machinery at Brooklands, and the fact that wagering was allowed, most races were run as handicaps. Duff was the fastest on the track for both wins. He also lost a number of races where he was the fastest. As Duffâs driving skills improved, his reputation began to put him at a disadvantage with the handicappers. In the off-season, Duff bought another old Fiat, the 18-litre pre-war racer called âMephistophelesâ.The Story of "Mephistopheles" by Capt. J. F. Duff, ''The Brooklands Gazette'', April 1925, Pages 384â385. In June, he took both Fiats to the [[Fanoe]] beach speed trials in [[Denmark]]. Duff set the fastest time of the meeting with a run at 165.9 km/h. He also took a class win with the S.61 at a speed of 149.2 km/h, the third fastest speed of the meeting. In 1922, Duff sold the S.61 and focused on making Mephistopheles faster and more reliable. [[Harry Ricardo]] made a set of [[aluminum]] [[piston]]s and raised the [[engine]]âs compression ratio. In May, Duff finished third in Brooklandsâ 100 Mile Handicap. In its next race, one of the Fiatâs [[engine block]]s detached from the [[crankcase]]. When the engine blew, the hood was torn off the car, just missing Duffâs head. Engine parts rained down on the track. Duff sold the car for scrap. 1922 saw the birth of Duff and Aldington, a dealership set up to sell the new [[Bentley]] car. Duff raced a Bentley at Brooklands. On August 28, he took a stock 3-litre model to the track where he made an attempt on the âDouble Twelveâ record (24 Hour runs were not allowed at Brooklands due to the noise). The car broke before he could achieve that goal but, in the process, Duff set new Class E world records for 1, 2, and 3 hours, 100 and 200 miles, and 100, 200, 300, and 400 km. Duff returned to Brooklands on September 27â28, driving both 12 hour shifts singlehanded to take the Double 12 ''Brooklands Gazette'', July 1924, Page 56. at an average of 86.52 mph, for a total distance of 2,082 miles (3,351 km). He also broke the Class E world records for 1 to 12 hours and all distances from 100 to 1,000 miles and 100 to 1,600 km. In total, he set 38 international class records. The Double 12 record was an absolute record, regardless of class. The event was depicted on the cover picture of the first edition of the [[Motor Sport (magazine)|''Brooklands Gazette'']], published in July 1924.''Motor Sport'', August 1949, Page 297. At Brooklandsâ autumn meeting, Duff appeared at the wheel of [[J.L. Dunne]]âs old 21-litre Blitzen [[Karl Benz|Benz]]. He lost the 100 Mile Handicap to [[J. G. Parry-Thomas|Parry Thomas]], despite lapping at 114.49 mph. Unable to stop the old car at the end of the last lap, Duff shot over the top of the banking, crashing through trees and a telegraph pole outside the circuit before finally coming to rest.In our time, high performance is commonplace and mechanical durability is a given with most cars. In Duffâs time, that was not the case. Now, automobile speed records over long distances and times rarely make the news. In Duffâs day, endurance and speed records set over distances like one or two thousand miles, twelve or twenty-four hours, were considered remarkable achievements. They were covered by both the automotive and the general press. In the 1920s, Duffâs speed records played as big a role as his Le Mans victory in establishing the name and reputation of Bentley cars as reliable high-speed sports/touring machines. Early in 1923, Duff learned of a new 24 Hour race to be held at [[24 Hours of Le Mans|Le Mans]]. He was the first entrant. [[W. O. Bentley]], the founder and then-owner of Bentley Motors, thought it was madness and that no car would finish. In the face of Duffâs determination, he agreed to have the car prepared at the factory and let his test driver, [[Frank Clement (racecar driver)|Frank Clement]], partner Duff. The Duff/Clement Bentley was one of the fastest cars, Duff setting the fastest lap at 9 mins 39 sec for the 10.726 mile lap.Georges Fraichard, ''The Le Mans Story'', The Sportsman's Book Club, 1956, Page 152. Rough track conditions took their toll as a flying stone holed the fuel tank, forcing Duff to run back to the pits. As only the drivers could work on the cars, Clement had to bicycle back with a can of gas to power the car back to the pits. Despite the drama, Duff and Clement finished a strong fourth.''Motor Sport'', November 1933, Page 17. More importantly, W.O. Bentley, who only went over at the last minute, became hooked on Le Mans, the race that would make his cars famous. Duff then took his Bentley to the Spanish Touring Car GP at [[Circuito Lasarte|Lasarte]]. Leading with two laps to go, he was hit in the face by a stone thrown up by a lapped car. Duff crashed into a wall, injuring his jaw and breaking some [[teeth]]. Despite that, he won first place in the 3 litre class, as he had easily outlasted and outdistanced his competition. "In token of his gallant drive Duff was awarded the 3-litre trophy anyway, there being no other finishers in the class." Cyril Posthumus, ''The Roaring Twenties, An Album of Early Motor Racing'', Page 44, Blandford Press, 1980. By 1924, Bentley was now fully committed to Le Mans. Duff was still a private entrant, using one of the dealershipâs cars. His car was prepared alongside the works entry using ideas Duff had come up with after the 1923 race. Partnered by Clement, in a race run in intense heat, Duff won handily, giving Bentley its first victory at Le Mans. In 1925, a carburetor fire ended Duffâs chances at Le Mans. On September 9â10, 1925, Duff went to the high-banked [[Autodrome de Linas-MontlhÃ©ry|MontlhÃ©ry]] track, near [[Paris]], for an attempt at the absolute 24 Hour Record. He had a special single-seater [[Charles Terres Weymann|Weymann]] body on his Bentley and works driver [[Dudley Benjafield]] as his co-driver. In driving rain, they did the first 12 hours at 97.7 mph but missed the 12 hour record. At 18 Â½ hours, the [[camshaft]] drive failed, ending the attempt. He was able to claim two world records: 1,000 Kilometres in 6 hrs, 23 mins, 55 secs and 1,000 miles in 10 hrs 15 mins 59secs.''The Observer'', September 20, 1925, Page 18. On September 21, Duff returned to MontlhÃ©ry with [[Woolf Barnato]] as his co-driver. Driving on a damp track in heavy mist, they covered 2,280 miles in 24 hours, averaging 95.02 mph.''The Manchester Guardian'', September 28, 1925, Page 13. They beat the previous record, held by the 9-litre [[Renault]] of Garfield and Plessier, by over 7 mph. Along the way, the 3-litre Bentley took 21 world records, including those for six and twelve hours, and 500, 1000, and 2000 miles.Regaining the 24 Hours World's Record for Great Britain, by Captain John F. Duff, ''Motor Sport'', November 1925, Pages 152â154. Looking for new challenges, Duff went to America in February 1926.''Aberdeen Daily News'', South Dakota, April 11, 1926, Page 2. He signed to drive a [[Harry Miller (auto racing)|Miller]] sponsored by the [[Elcar]] Automobile Company in the [[Indianapolis 500]], following the death of Herbert Jones, who was killed attempting to qualify for the race in the Elcar Special.''Springfield Republican'', May 30, 1926, Page 5. In a race shortened to 400 miles by rain, Duff finished 9th. The next AAA championship event was on the 1.25 mile [[board track racing|board track]] at [[Altoona, Pennsylvania]] on June 12. Duff finished 3rd in the 250 mile race, two laps down.''Oregonian'', June 13, 1926, Page 86. The next race was on the Rockingham board track in [[Salem, New Hampshire|Salem]], [[New Hampshire]]. A puncture pitched Duffâs car sideways, throwing him from the car. "John Duff of Indianapolis, Ind., wrecked his machine and suffered a broken collar bone when his car crashed through the top rail and dropped clear of the track." ''Seattle Daily Times'', July 6, 1926, Page 16. Duff suffered painful bone and muscle injuries, and a concussion that affected his vision. Knowing that his competitiveness would be compromised, and having promised his wife that he would quit if he suffered another serious injury, Duff retired from racing. == Later life == After the accident, Duff brought his family over from England. They settled in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]], near [[Los Angeles]]. Duff opened a [[fencing]] academy where he trained many of the movie stars of the day. He doubled for his friend [[Gary Cooper]] and others in [[swordfighting]] scenes in [[Hollywood]] films. He also taught fencing at [[UCLA]]. In 1932, he coached some of his students on the [[U.S. Olympic team]]. When the [[Great Depression|Depression]] led to a decline in the demand for fencing instruction, Duff moved his family to China. The Duff familyâs settlement at Kuling had prospered over the years and turned into a thriving resort. They stayed in China from 1932 to 1934, when they moved back to England. In January 1935 he became a member of the [[British Racing Drivers' Club]].Noted in the Clubâs general Committee Meeting held on January 28, 1935. He was proposed by L. G. Callingham and seconded by H. D. Parker. Duff continued to be a successful swordsman into the late 1930s. He also did well in business. The money he made allowed him to indulge his passion for horses. He became a competitive steeplechaser and show jumper. John Duff died in a riding accident in [[Epping Forest]] on January 8, 1958. == Canadian connection == John Duff was born in China in 1895. Like everyone else in the [[British Empire]], Canadians were subjects of the reigning monarch, not citizens of any country. If there had been Canadian citizenship, Duff would have qualified via his Canadian parents. John Duff can be found on the [[Canadian Census]] for both 1901 and 1911. There was a category for âNationalityâ. In both cases, Duffâs was listed as Canadian. When John Duff started racing in 1920, he had lived a significant part of his life in Canada. Although there was no Canadian citizenship until 1947, Canada had issued its own [[passport]]s since the 1860s. As late as 1932, John Duff carried a Canadian passport â which means that he carried one throughout his racing career. In a newspaper interview given after his last crash, Duff was clear about his Canadian origins.
